Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: This class is a complete gut.  I learned how to truly fluff through an entire Yale class.
I learned so much about ancient ships and ancient civilizations.
How to write about art history
I learned the topics that I wrote my three papers on very well.
I learned about the cultures of ancient cultures such as Egyptian and Aegean.
My writing skills improved significantly.
How to engage with works of art and understand their composition and thematic elements
I developed valuable writing skills through a type of research I have not done before.
Learned a great variety of information about general ancient empires as well as a lot of information about ancient ships.
Gained some knowledge of marine archaeology and ancient history. Good practice writing short research papers.
I learned a great deal not only about history, by about how we know what we do/the process by which historical knowledge is gained, verified, and catalogued.

I learned a lot about ships, and Professor Foster was incredibly knowledgeable. It is an extremely interesting and niche topic and a unique opportunity to learn something out of my usual subjectsand that's what college is all about!

The value of this course was writing papers and preparing projects--definitely enjoyed the research opportunities the assignments afforded. Overall, while the lectures were engaging and interesting, I am disappointed they did not center more on naval archaeology. The class was mainly concerned with the cultural milieu surrounding "Ancient Ships" rather than with the ships themselves.
I obtained a detailed understanding of the history of many famous ships and other ships alike. I received an intelligence on the broad range of ships that have sailed throughout our world
writing and deduction skills
I learned a lot about ancient history and the use of ships. I learned about the parts of a ship and many aspects of maritime technology.
I learned much about maritime technology and archeology.
I didn't really learn anything, just had fun!
History of ancient ships
I learned about ancient ships from ancient Egypt up to the Roman era and maratime archeology in the modern day.
I learned how to evaluate art and archaeology
This class helped me gain an understanding of some interesting history.
I learned to look at art from a new historical perspective, especially in examining the purposes of each feature in ships or in art.
I learned about ancient archaeology across the world. Also ships.
Better at assessing historical evidence
ancient ships/ shipbuilding
I learned a great deal about the ancient world, from Egypt to Ancient Greece, and how certain elements of their culture were tied to seafaring.
I gained a surface understanding of a number of ancient civilizations, particularly though a study of their artwork. I also received practice in writing short, independent research papers.

Useless gut class. There are more interesting easy classes to take. Don't take this one. She doesn't even talk about ships most of the time?? Like why, in a class named 'Ancient Ships,' is so much of the time spent on egyptian tombs. There are better ways to look at ancient ships, surely. Maybe more time on the greeks?? Or the oceans?? Or China?? Idk.

This course has a wonderful, immersive professor who is so talented and knowledgeable!  The only weakness for this course was that the course packet was expensive and ultimately not needed; however, it did serve as a great supplement to course material.  Additionally, the course's name (Ancient Ships) should be updated to reflect the fact that this is a primarily a course about ancient civilizations, and only its intersection with ships.
This course hardly touched on ancient ships, which is a shame. It was more of an archeology and art history course than anything else.
Lectures were not the most conducive to student engagement
The papers are actually useful and force learning with enough freedom to do something interesting. The lectures are not as exciting.

I found lectures pretty excruciating and opted not to attend the vast majority. The papers were cool because I had an opportunity to explore topics that I am more interested in than what was covered in lectures.
Great professor, interesting topics, not as many boats as you would think
I think that this course allows its students to be very independent in their learning of material.
Lecture was very interesting and informative, provided several opportunities to engage with material critically

The strengths include very easy to understand lectures and engaging presentations.
Weakness was only the trip to Mystic Seaport the every student had to make.
It's an interesting course with a light workload. However, it would have been more cohensive if the assignments had more to do with the lectures.

I was attracted to the idea of a seminar, but the huge enrollment meant it got switched to a lecture with much less engagement that initially expected. After a couple weeks, the vast majority of the group stopped showing up, meaning we had a lecture hall with only a dozen or so kids, but still couldnt participate in the sorts of discussions I hoped to have.
Strength was the professor and flexibility of the course.
lectures are quite dry
Great class, very engaging. The professor cares very much about the subject, incredibly interesting.
The course was well taught, but could have been organized a little better.

Strengths: absolute ultimate gut class, super easy, you don't have to go to any lecture at all, meet really fun party people, can write the papers the night before and still get an A
Weaknesses: none
Great class overall, loved professor Foster. Was very very interesting at times.
I have no recommendations. Great class!
Great class! Only weakness was that people didnt show up.
Great lectures

I really liked that the class was full of different information from lecture to lecture, but I think it could have focused more on ships rather than art as a whole. However, it was still interesting to learn about the different components of historical art.
The course dives deeply into ancient archaeology, but there is not much on ships themselves.
interesting history

The lectures were very well prepared and informative, as were the guest lectures. I would like to look closer at the individual and typologies of ships in the ancient world, and perhaps look at other areas, such as Latin America and East Asia.

The lectures provide a great introduction to a number of ancient civilizations through a study of their artwork. The assignments are very open-ended and give a great deal of freedom. Finally, the class is low-work and low-stress. The main weakness of the course was that it was not about ships. Most lectures had a extremely tenuous connection to ships, and most of the time was spent discussing ancient artwork. Additionally, I was very disappointed by the guest lecture about maritime law; it lacked cohesion and clarity.

Useless gut class. There are more interesting easy classes to take. Don't take this one. She doesn't even talk about ships most of the time?? Like why, in a class named 'Ancient Ships,' is so much of the time spent on egyptian tombs. There are better ways to look at ancient ships, surely. Maybe more time on the greeks?? Or the oceans?? Or China?? Idk.
Complete gut.
Yes 1000% for a 5th class

ABSOLUTELY.  Professor Foster is genuinely one of the nicest, most kindhearted professors I know.  She is incredibly talented and the knowledge she has to share is fascinating.  The workload for this course is very manageable and would be a great 5th course.  This course has my highest recommendation!
No, I wouldn't recommend this course because it's extremely dry, little feedback is given on the assignments, and you really don't talk much about ancient ships.
If you need a chill class

It is pretty easy (three papers with not too harsh grading). I usually started papers a few days before the deadline and cranked them out in like 6-7 hours or so. I took them seriously and it was reflected in my grades. I don't think most people that take this course actually have an interest in ancient ships lol but I do so I thought the papers were fun to write. Nice course to throw on top if you already have four or five courses lined up.
Absolutely - you will become a better writer.
Yes, I enjoyed engaging with new material in a compelling and natural way
Yes, it was a fantastic course to learn about ancient history
Yes.
I would definitely recommend this - Prof Foster is clearly very passionate about the subject, and you will learn some interesting stuff. Not too much work, definitely an enjoyable 5th class.
Yes
Yes, if you're looking for an easy but interesting fifth class/ social science or humanities credit.

Definitely a cool subject and Professor Foster is a great lecturer, but in general the level of engagement was very low due to kids taking the class with hopes of doing very little work. If youre looking for an easy credit, this will do, but Id instead hope kids take the class based on genuine interest.
Yes! Professor Foster is amazing, and the section is really small and fun. You have a lot of choice and flexibility in the course to pursue your interests.

I would recommend this class to another student depending on what his or her motives for taking the class are--personally, I took the course because I wanted to learn more about naval archaeology, so I was a bit disappointed (though I really enjoyed the writing assignments). If someone is simply looking for a fun, not-too-intensive course, then I would highly recommend it.
Yes.

Absolutely! The content of the course was interesting. The style in which the course was thought was very clear and informative, but at the same time the course was not stressful. The assignments were very enjoyable because, they gave me a chance to research the topics that I am interested in.
Yes, it was a very fun experience to be able to learn about ships. I very much enjoyed my visit to the Mystic Seaport Museum.
I would, as it is a course to lighten the work load of any student with a tough schedule.

You NEED to take this class. It's the best class I've ever taken at Yale (not kidding). It's unbelievably easy to get an A, and the class is just so much fun! You don't need to go to any of the lectures (maybe 20 people showed up out of the like 140 people taking it). You don't need to do any of the readings. I literally didn't do a single reading and did really well. I met such fun people in the class as well!!  Also we never even talked about ships in the class, all we
Absolutely
Great class, take it
Professor Foster is excellent! This was a GREAT class. Take it for sure
Great class

If you are interested in learning about different types of artincluding the compositionsand about different ancient civilizations, or if you are looking to take this course for a lower workload, then definitely take this class. However, if you do not like these subject matters and do not enjoy a class full of students not paying attention, this is not the course for you.
Definitely take this course

I would take this! Be warned, though, the course dives deeply into ancient archaeology, but there is not much on ships themselves. The trip to Mystic, CT is a fun excursion to get off campus and see the ship history that New England has to offer. Pretty cool stuff! Anyway, hopefully there will be more ship stuff next year!
Yes I feel that the information was interesting
yes very interesting
I would, if you have a general interest in ancient history in the Mediterranean.

Despite the title, this class very rarely discussed ships. If you're interested in taking a class about ancient artwork, this class is good -- interesting lectures, open-ended papers, and low workload. If you're looking for a class about ships or maritime archeology, look elsewhere.

Useless gut class. There are more interesting easy classes to take. Don't take this one. She doesn't even talk about ships most of the time?? Like why, in a class named 'Ancient Ships,' is so much of the time spent on egyptian tombs. There are better ways to look at ancient ships, surely. Maybe more time on the greeks?? Or the oceans?? Or China?? Idk.
